text:
SORAYA CHEMALY: I
write about issues

that cut across religion,
politics, education, science,

technology, anything really
that kind of reframes

a problem from the
perspective of social justice,

particularly as it pertains
to women, particularly as it
pertains to intersectionality.

And actually, it's just
a intellectual framework,

and so you can apply it
in any of these contexts.
So that's what I talk about.

One of my main objectives
was that girls and women

stop getting sick, like
physically and mentally ill,

because of social prohibitions
on their defending

themselves or
expressing themselves

or demanding accountability
from the people around them.

So I document the ways
in which that happens,

the ways in which the diversion
or suppression or repression

or very unhealthy manifestations
of anger come back to bite us.

And I acknowledge that
there are real penalties

to expressing your own
needs because that's
what expressing anger is.

You're literally expressing
a need or a perception
of risk or threat.

And so the question is, why
don't the people around you
care?

What you're saying
is important to you.

The subtitle of the book is
"The Power of Women's Anger,"

and actually, we had a long
conversation-- my editor,

my agent, and I-- about
whether to qualify power.

And we ended up
leaving it unqualified

because, in fact, it can
be powerfully positive,

or as we generally know
and perceive, negative.

And so the book is
about the tax on women

for feeling or
displaying this emotion

and how it's
socially constructed

really to protect
the status quo,

to protect status
quo of inequalities.

If you're angry as
a woman, chances

are that the first
response is going

to be mockery or
belittlement, which

is kind of a form of
infantilization, which

ultimately means that
you need to be governed

and that your anger doesn't
have political legitimacy.

And in fact, the anger
that many of us feel

is the most rational
response to the situation
that we find ourselves in.

And it's not an anger of
resentment or contempt,

but an anger of
hope and compassion.

One of the things that
I've been keeping track of

is disparate responses to
when women tell their stories.

And what we've seen
in a movement like Me

Too or Black Lives
Matters, which

was started by three
queer women of color,

what we see is that the social
response to those narratives,

to those perspectives is often
so negative, that there's
a lot of doubt.

And I think that often comes
down to identity threats.

This knowledge is a threat
to identity and status,

and so the cognitive response is
to deny or silence or aggress.

And after hashtag movements
like #YesAllWomen,

#NotOK, where you had
millions of women pouring out

these stories, some of them
for the first time, some

of them for the first
time even acknowledging

these experiences, there was
a lot of defensive denial.

And all of these studies
show double-digit gaps

in men believing women and
believing these stories.

And so the question is, why
wouldn't they believe women?

Especially, which is
so often the case,

when women have to come
together by the thousands, tens

of thousands, and millions
to say the same thing.

That's how big the
credibility gap is.
It's never one woman.

And I think a lot of that has to
do with this notion of identity
protective cognition.
So if all of a sudden women--

and it might be, as
people are fond of saying,

my sister, my mother, my
daughter-- are saying,
I'm not protected.

I'm telling you that
I'm not protected.
I don't feel safe.
I'm hyper-vigilant.

I'm sexually harassed at work
or in my school or in my sport.
That translates into failure.

I am failing to protect,
and that's a threat.
That's a threat to identity.

And so we see that all the
time when women are angry.
Their anger is downgraded.

The language around
it is demeaning
or minimizing or trivializing.

I'm irritated, I'm stressed,
it's such a bother,

instead of just
saying, you know,

I'm really angry
because X happened

and having someone just listen
and say, what can I do to help?
